sn46.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn46.5:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn46.5:1.4.eng: How are the awakening factors defined?”

sn46.5:1.5.eng: “Mendicant, they’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.

sn46.5:1.6.pli: Idha, bhikkhu, satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …pe…
sn46.5:1.6.eng: A mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.5:1.7.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn46.5:1.7.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.5:1.8.pli: Tassime satta bojjhaṅge bhāvayato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
sn46.5:1.8.eng: As they develop the seven awakening factors, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

sn46.5:1.9.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn46.5:1.10.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn46.5:1.10.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn46.5:1.11.eng: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.”

sn46.50:1.1.pli: “Bāhiraṃ, bhikkhave, aṅganti karitvā nāññaṃ ekaṅgampi samanupassāmi sattannaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ uppādāya, yathayidaṃ—bhikkhave, kalyāṇamittatā.
sn46.50:1.1.eng: “Taking into account exterior factors, mendicants, I do not see a single one that gives rise to the seven awakening factors like good friendship. …”

sn46.50:1.2.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—satta bojjhaṅge bhāvessati, satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkarissati.

sn46.50:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto satta bojjhaṅge bhāveti, satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaroti?

sn46.50:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ …pe…

sn46.50:1.5.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.

sn46.50:1.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto satta bojjhaṅge bhāveti, satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkarotī”ti.

sn46.51:1.2.pli: “Pañcannañca, bhikkhave, nīvaraṇānaṃ sattannañca bojjhaṅgānaṃ āhārañca anāhārañca desessāmi;
sn46.51:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you what fuels and what starves the five hindrances and the seven awakening factors.

sn46.51:1.4.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, āhāro anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā kāmacchandassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya?
sn46.51:1.4.eng: And what fuels the arising of sensual desire, or, when it has arisen, makes it increase and grow?

sn46.51:1.5.eng: There is the feature of beauty.

sn46.51:1.6.eng: Frequent irrational application of mind to that

sn46.51:1.7.pli: ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā kāmacchandassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya.
sn46.51:1.7.eng: fuels the arising of sensual desire, or, when it has arisen, makes it increase and grow.

sn46.51:2.2.eng: There is the feature of harshness.

sn46.51:2.3.eng: Frequent irrational application of mind to that

sn46.51:2.4.pli: ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā byāpādassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā byāpādassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya.
sn46.51:2.4.eng: fuels the arising of ill will, or, when it has arisen, makes it increase and grow.

sn46.51:3.1.eng: And what fuels the arising of dullness and drowsiness, or, when they have arisen, makes them increase and grow?

sn46.51:3.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, arati tandi vijambhitā bhattasammado cetaso ca līnattaṃ.
sn46.51:3.2.eng: There is discontent, sloth, yawning, sleepiness after eating, and mental sluggishness.

sn46.51:3.3.eng: Frequent irrational application of mind to that

sn46.51:3.4.pli: ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā thinamiddhassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā thinamiddhassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya.
sn46.51:3.4.eng: fuels the arising of dullness and drowsiness, or, when they have arisen, makes them increase and grow.

sn46.52:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu.
sn46.52:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn46.52:1.3.eng: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.

sn46.52:1.4.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyāmā”ti.
sn46.52:1.4.eng: Why don’t we visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”

sn46.52:2.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn46.52:2.1.eng: Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.

sn46.52:2.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṃ:
sn46.52:2.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. The wanderers said to them:

sn46.52:3.1.pli: “Samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo sāvakānaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ deseti:
sn46.52:3.1.eng: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama teaches his disciples like this:

sn46.52:3.2.pli: ‘etha tumhe, bhikkhave, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvethā’ti.
sn46.52:3.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, please give up the five hindrances—corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom—and truly develop the seven awakening factors.’

sn46.52:3.3.pli: Mayampi kho, āvuso, sāvakānaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desema:

sn46.52:3.4.pli: ‘etha tumhe, āvuso, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvethā’ti.
sn46.52:3.4.eng: ‘Reverends, please give up the five hindrances—corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom—and truly develop the seven awakening factors.’

sn46.52:3.5.pli: Idha no, āvuso, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ samaṇassa vā gotamassa amhākaṃ vā, yadidaṃ—dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesanaṃ, anusāsaniyā vā anusāsanin”ti?
sn46.52:3.5.eng: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”

sn46.52:4.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃsu nappaṭikkosiṃsu;
sn46.52:4.1.eng: Those mendicants neither approved nor rejected that statement of the wanderers of other religions.

sn46.52:4.2.eng: They got up from their seat, thinking:

sn46.52:4.3.eng: “We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”

sn46.52:4.4.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn46.52:4.4.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn46.52:5.1.pli: “Idha mayaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisimha.

sn46.52:5.4.pli: yannūna mayaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyāmā’ti.

sn46.52:5.5.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodimha.

sn46.52:5.6.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdimha. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho amhe, bhante, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṃ:

sn46.52:6.1.pli: ‘Samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo sāvakānaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ deseti “etha tumhe, bhikkhave, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvethā”ti.

sn46.52:6.2.pli: Mayampi kho, āvuso, sāvakānaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desema:

sn46.52:6.3.pli: “etha tumhe, āvuso, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvethā”ti.

sn46.52:6.4.pli: Idha no, āvuso, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ samaṇassa vā gotamassa amhākaṃ vā, yadidaṃ—dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesanaṃ, anusāsaniyā vā anusāsanin’ti?

sn46.52:7.1.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandimha nappaṭikkosimha, anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamimha:

sn46.52:8.1.eng: “Mendicants, when wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them:

sn46.52:8.2.pli: ‘atthi panāvuso, pariyāyo, yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma pañca nīvaraṇā dasa honti, satta bojjhaṅgā catuddasā’ti.
sn46.52:8.2.eng: ‘But reverends, is there a way in which the five hindrances become ten and the seven awakening factors become fourteen?’

sn46.52:8.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā na ceva sampāyissanti, uttariñca vighātaṃ āpajjissanti.
sn46.52:8.3.eng: Questioned like this, the wanderers of other religions would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.

sn46.52:8.5.eng: Because they’re out of their element.

sn46.52:8.6.pli: Nāhaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo imesaṃ pañhānaṃ veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheyya, aññatra tathāgatena vā tathāgatasāvakena vā ito vā pana sutvā.
sn46.52:8.6.eng: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.

sn46.52:9.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma pañca nīvaraṇā dasa honti?
sn46.52:9.1.eng: And what is the way in which the five hindrances become ten?

sn46.52:9.2.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ kāmacchando tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ, yadapi bahiddhā kāmacchando tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ.
sn46.52:9.2.eng: Sensual desire for what is internal is a hindrance; and sensual desire for what is external is also a hindrance.

sn46.52:9.3.pli: ‘Kāmacchandanīvaraṇan’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:9.3.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the hindrance of sensual desire’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:9.4.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ byāpādo tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ, yadapi bahiddhā byāpādo tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ.
sn46.52:9.4.eng: Ill will for what is internal is a hindrance; and ill will for what is external is also a hindrance.

sn46.52:9.5.pli: ‘Byāpādanīvaraṇan’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:9.5.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the hindrance of ill will’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:9.6.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, thinaṃ tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ, yadapi middhaṃ tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ.
sn46.52:9.6.eng: Dullness is a hindrance; and drowsiness is also a hindrance.

sn46.52:9.7.pli: ‘Thinamiddhanīvaraṇan’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:9.7.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the hindrance of dullness and drowsiness’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:9.8.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, uddhaccaṃ tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ, yadapi kukkuccaṃ tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ.
sn46.52:9.8.eng: Restlessness is a hindrance; and remorse is also a hindrance.

sn46.52:9.9.pli: ‘Uddhaccakukkuccanīvaraṇan’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:9.9.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the hindrance of restlessness and remorse’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:9.10.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ dhammesu vicikicchā tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ, yadapi bahiddhā dhammesu vicikicchā tadapi nīvaraṇaṃ.
sn46.52:9.10.eng: Doubt about internal things is a hindrance; and doubt about external things is also a hindrance.

sn46.52:9.11.pli: ‘Vicikicchānīvaraṇan’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:9.11.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the hindrance of doubt’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:9.12.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma pañca nīvaraṇā dasa honti.
sn46.52:9.12.eng: This is the way in which the five hindrances become ten.

sn46.52:10.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma satta bojjhaṅgā catuddasa honti?
sn46.52:10.1.eng: And what is the way in which the seven awakening factors become fourteen?

sn46.52:10.2.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ dhammesu sati tadapi satisambojjhaṅgo, yadapi bahiddhā dhammesu sati tadapi satisambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:10.2.eng: Mindfulness of internal things is the awakening factor of mindfulness; and mindfulness of external things is also the awakening factor of mindfulness.

sn46.52:10.3.pli: ‘Satisambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:10.3.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of mindfulness’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:11.1.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ dhammesu paññāya pavicinati pavicarati parivīmaṃsamāpajjati tadapi dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, yadapi bahiddhā dhammesu paññāya pavicinati pavicarati parivīmaṃsamāpajjati tadapi dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:11.1.eng: Investigating, exploring, and inquiring into internal things with wisdom is the awakening factor of investigation of principles; and investigating, exploring, and inquiring into external things with wisdom is also the awakening factor of investigation of principles.

sn46.52:11.2.pli: ‘Dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:11.2.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of investigation of principles’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:12.1.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ vīriyaṃ tadapi vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, yadapi cetasikaṃ vīriyaṃ tadapi vīriyasambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:12.1.eng: Physical energy is the awakening factor of energy; and mental energy is also the awakening factor of energy.

sn46.52:12.2.pli: ‘Vīriyasambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:12.2.eng: That’s how what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of energy’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:13.1.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, savitakkasavicārā pīti tadapi pītisambojjhaṅgo, yadapi avitakkaavicārā pīti tadapi pītisambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:13.1.eng: Rapture while placing the mind and keeping it connected is the awakening factor of rapture; and rapture without placing the mind and keeping it connected is also the awakening factor of rapture.

sn46.52:13.2.pli: ‘Pītisambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:13.2.eng: In this way what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of rapture’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:14.1.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, kāyappassaddhi tadapi passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, yadapi cittappassaddhi tadapi passaddhisambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:14.1.eng: Physical tranquility is the awakening factor of tranquility; and mental tranquility is also the awakening factor of tranquility.

sn46.52:14.2.pli: ‘Passaddhisambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:14.2.eng: In this way what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of tranquility’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:15.1.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, savitakko savicāro samādhi tadapi samādhisambojjhaṅgo, yadapi avitakkaavicāro samādhi tadapi samādhisambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:15.1.eng: Immersion while placing the mind and keeping it connected is the awakening factor of immersion; and immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected is also the awakening factor of immersion.

sn46.52:15.2.pli: ‘Samādhisambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:15.2.eng: In this way what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of immersion’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:16.1.pli: Yadapi, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ dhammesu upekkhā tadapi upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo, yadapi bahiddhā dhammesu upekkhā tadapi upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.
sn46.52:16.1.eng: Equanimity for internal things is the awakening factor of equanimity; and equanimity for external things is also the awakening factor of equanimity.

sn46.52:16.2.pli: ‘Upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo’ti iti hidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchati. Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena dvayaṃ hoti.
sn46.52:16.2.eng: In this way what is concisely referred to as ‘the awakening factor of equanimity’ becomes twofold.

sn46.52:16.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma satta bojjhaṅgā catuddasā”ti.
sn46.52:16.3.eng: This is the way in which the seven awakening factors become fourteen.”
